title: Big funds push miners to get tougher with industry bodies on climate
text:
Institutional investors have stepped up the pressure on BHP to lay the groundwork for severing ties with the Minerals Council of Australia before an important shareholder vote next month on the miner's response to climate change.

Investors with $16 trillion in funds under management want mining companies to force industry associations to commit to more ambitious emissions reduction targets.

BHP has been accused of positioning itself as a climate champion, yet belonging to associations that seek to undermine international commitments such as the Paris Agreement.

In 2015 in Paris, countries including Australia pledged to take action to limit global warming to as close to 1.5 degrees as possible.

The Australian Financial Review has seen a letter, organised by Climate Change Action 100+, which is being sent to BHP, South32 and other companies in Australia to outline what they should be demanding from the Minerals Council.

Lobby group Coal21, which advocates low-emissions coal technologies such as carbon capture and storage, and the NSW Minerals Council are also named as associations that "continue to undermine effective climate policy".
description: Institutional investors have stepped up the pressure on BHP to sever ties with the Minerals Council of Australia ahead of a shareholder vote on climate change.
